column1: b'supervised node classi\xef\xac\x81cation by learning the inference of node labels on graph\ntopology.To bridge the connection between two nodes

column5: which can make the inference conveniently deduced\nfrom one node to another node.For learning the inference process
column6: we further\nintroduce meta-optimization on structure relations from training nodes to validation\nnodes
column7: such that the learnt graph inference capability can be better self-adapted to\ntesting nodes.'

column1: b'These aforementioned works usually boil down to a general classi\xef\xac\x81cation task
column2: \nwhere the model is learnt on a training set and selected by checking a validation set.However
column3: they\ndo not put great efforts on how to learn to infer from one node to another node on a topological graph
column4: \nespecially in the few-shot regime.In this paper
column5: we propose a graph inference learning (GIL) framework to teach the model itself to\nadaptively infer from reference labeled nodes to those query unlabeled nodes
column6: and \xef\xac\x81nally boost the\nperformance of semi-supervised node classi\xef\xac\x81cation in the case of a few number of labeled samples.'

column2: GIL attempts to infer the unlabeled nodes from those observed nodes by\nbuilding between-node relations.The between-node relations are structured as the integration of\nnode attributes
column4: and graph topological structures.It means that the similarity\nbetween two nodes is decided from three aspects: the consistency of node attributes

column1: b'1.The local\nstructures anchored around each node as well as the attributes of nodes therein are jointly encoded\nwith graph convolution (Defferrard et al.
column2: 2016) for the sake of high-level feature extraction.For the\nbetween-node path reachability
column3: we adopt the random walk algorithm to obtain the characteristics\nfrom a labeled reference node vi to a query unlabeled node vj in a given graph.'

column1: b'Based on the\ncomputed node representation and between-node reachability
column2: the structure relations can be obtained\nby computing the similar scores/relationships from reference nodes to unlabeled nodes in a graph.Inspired by the recent meta-learning strategy (Finn et al.
column4: we learn to infer the structure\nrelations from a training set to a validation set
column5: which can bene\xef\xac\x81t the generalization capability of the\nlearned model.In other words
column6: our proposed GIL attempts to learn some transferable knowledge\nunderlying in the structure relations from training samples to validation samples
column7: such that the learned\nstructure relations can be better self-adapted to the new testing stage.'

b'We summarize the main contributions of this work as three folds:

\xe2\x80\xa2We propose a novel graph inference learning framework by building structure relations to
infer unknown node labels from those labeled nodes in an end-to-end way.The structure
relations are well de\xef\xac\x81ned by jointly considering node attributes
